minor.introduction:
In biochemistry, you'll study the molecules and mechanisms essential to life, as well as¬†the molecular basis of disease. Apply state-of-the art approaches and equipment¬†to understand¬†molecular genetics, structural biology, signal transduction, chemical biology, and bioinformatics.¬†
BMSc: A First-Entry, Guided Path to a Career in Medicine or Dentistry¬†
The Bachelor of Medical Sciences (BMSc) Program, offered jointly by the Faculty of Science and the Schulich School of Medicine  Dentistry,¬†teaches you¬†the basic medical sciences at an advanced level.¬†If you‚Äôre interested in any of the Medical Sciences programs, apply to Medical Sciences First Entry. Then, you¬†are assured admission to Year 3¬†BMSc,¬†provided¬†you¬†complete¬†Medical Sciences 1 and 2¬†successfully.

h4: First Things First: Years 1  2 Are Different
Apply to the Faculty of Science:
p: Your first step (first entry) is the Faculty of Science for Years 1 and 2 in Medical Sciences. Although your intended program is part of the Bachelor of Medical Sciences (BMSc) Program, BMSc is a "second-entry" program.

p.#text: For Year 3, you apply to the BMSc program. You can enter the BMSc in Year 3 from other programs, but you have guaranteed* admission to Year 3 if you start in Medical Sciences. (*OK, it's only guaranteed if you complete all required courses with the requisite scores.).

minor.introduction:
You use technology all the time. Digital environments are embedded in every industry. But in order to control and shape them, you need to understand them. That‚Äôs where Digital Humanities comes in.
There‚Äôs no other program like this in Canada! It‚Äôs a blend of Arts  Humanities and Computer Science. You‚Äôll gain a new perspective into literature, language, history and art through a digital lens. You‚Äôll also learn by doing. That includes programming, designing, and even coding. These are all in-demand skills for the current job market.

minor.introduction:
Learning French is one of the most practical things you can do to get a competitive edge for jobs in Canada ‚Ä¶ or around the world. No matter what type of career you‚Äôre interested in, knowing English and French is a huge asset.
We‚Äôre the second largest French department in Ontario with ample opportunities to learn. What‚Äôs a better way than completely immersing yourself? Live the French language and culture of Qu√©bec by earning credits towards your degree at Trois-Pistoles.
French isn‚Äôt just about learning the language. It‚Äôs about gaining an appreciation and understanding of French civilization, literary theory, linguistics and more. It‚Äôs for those who are ready to open their world to another culture.

minor.introduction:
How does a four-letter DNA code become a living being? Why do animals and humans behave the way they do? How many species are yet to be discovered?
When you study Biology at Western, you'll learn to view the natural world at the cellular level using the latest in analytical instrumentation. You'll experience our flora and fauna as interconnected global ecosystems through sophisticated experimental design and data analysis. And you'll also have the opportunity to get your hands dirty with a field research project in a biodiverse location like the Adirondacks, Costa Rica, or Ecuador.
After you graduate, the world is yours - you can go on to graduate school, get a medical or law degree, or join an industry or government team focused on lab quality assurance, research, policy and more.

minor.introduction:
Climate change? Try climate emergency. The science and politics of climate are controversial and they‚Äôre only part of what you‚Äôll study in Geography and Environment. Along with global systems, biodiversity, cities, energy, food  agriculture and more.
As an informed and responsible citizen, you‚Äôll graduate ready for many careers:

Environmental Consultant
Medical Geographer
Hydrologist
Cartographer
Wildlife Ecologist
Urban Planner
CIS Analyst
Diplomat

Think of Geography and Environment as the perfect combination of natural sciences and social sciences. You have flexibility to do more science to earn a Bachelor of Science, or more social science for a Bachelor of Arts. Click into ‚Äúmore‚Äù to see modules and sample courses.

minor.introduction:
Humans are complex. How we‚Äôve come to be this way is what you study in Anthropology. You‚Äôll look at human behaviour, biology and society from the last four to five million years to better understand where we are today.
We study using four fields:

Archeology
Biological anthropology
Linguistic anthropology
Sociocultural anthropology

Understanding humans is valuable for almost any future career. But if you‚Äôre not sure if Anthropology is for you, try it out during the common first year. It compliments anything else you‚Äôre studying related to the human experience. That includes topics in Social Science, Arts  Humanities‚Ä¶ even Science and Health Studies.

minor.introduction:
How do we get things done better? Better might be faster, easier, or more ethically‚Äîor maybe all of those and more. The constant for scholars in DAN Department of Management  Organizational Studies is data. We want to understand the evidence behind ‚Äúbetter.‚Äù
Our undergraduate program is one of the first to provide an evidence-based approach to the study of management. You join about 2800 undergraduate students studying management from multiple perspectives and with many career goals.
We provide all academic requirements, fully‚ÄØaccredited, for the Chartered Professional Accountant (CPA) designation, as well as the Certified Human Resource Professional (CHRP) designation. You may also pursue a commercial pilot‚Äôs license as part of our Commercial Aviation Management program.
Learn more about programs in Management  Organizational Studies

minor.introduction:
Studying literature nurtures, strengthens, and matures the skills needed in every profession:

Communication
Balancing complexity
Empathy across differences
Persuasion
Storytelling

Not to mention the ability to track, analyze, and critique long collections of words! At Western, we study Canadian, British, American, global, and Indigenous literature. You can start with the earliest classics, like Beowulf. You can follow a contemporary novel, like Room, as it is adapted to stage and screen. English Studies at Western will make you a stronger professional and a clearer citizen, and it will support your humanity throughout your life.

minor.introduction:
What do we have? What do we need? There never seems to be enough resources to cover the need, so we end up making choices. Individuals, business, governments, markets‚Äîwe all face economic choice.
Studying economics gives you analytical insight into these choices and their consequences. Economists commonly study things like trade, tax policy, and wage practices. At Western, we also bring economics to bear on domestic violence, disability insurance, racial profiling, and nonprofit fundraising.

From bioinformatics to social networking, computer science drives innovation in nearly every area of our lives. But it's more than just data and code‚Äîit‚Äôs¬†also about imagination.¬†How much farther¬†can we go? What kind of impact will we have along the way?¬†
Western‚Äôs¬†flagship programs in big data, game development, cybersecurity, financial modelling, and more will send your career in directions you might never imagine.¬†Outside the classroom, you can develop your entrepreneurial and communication skills for start-up¬†projects, or¬†work one-on-one with faculty on a funded summer research project.¬†
Apply the theories. Write the code. Build the databases. Answer the big questions.

minor.introduction:
To understand where we are and where we‚Äôre going, we must understand where we‚Äôve been. In History at Western, you‚Äôll imagine how life used to be using critical thinking and analytic skills. You research, ask questions, debate and write. These skills are useful for all sorts of careers including law, government, education, IT and finance.
Explore the world from Canada to Latin America to the Far East. Keep your interests narrow or diversify. There are usually about 70 undergraduate history courses to choose from each year. Themes range from culture  society to international relations, war, business and environment. Click into ‚Äúmore‚Äù to see sample courses.

But that‚Äôs not your only choice with a degree in chemistry. You might go into medicine and healthcare, law, business, or education. What we know is you‚Äôll¬†graduate¬†a problem-solver ready to tackle big world challenges.

minor.introduction:
Film is one of the most influential forms of visual culture. Whether you grew up on Disney, you‚Äôre still waiting for your Hogwarts letter, or you believe Spielberg can do no wrong. But now, you‚Äôre ready to look deeper. We strip away the princesses and talking animals to critically examine, analyze and explain film.
Where will you go after graduation? Film and television, media and entertainment, marketing, museums and business to name a few. Your new set of skills will be attractive to many employers:

Communication
Critical Examination
Cultural Awareness
Influence and Persuasion
Problem Solving
Reporting and Editing
Technical and Media Literary
Visual Perception/Articulation

If you dream of being a filmmaker, get the tools and guidance to make your own film through workshops, festivals and events held by the Western Undergraduate Film Society (WUFS).

Farmers, guild artisans and merchants
Food culture and nutrition
Medieval heroes and villains like Joan of Arc, Robin Hood and Loki
Medieval manuscripts
Medieval music
Representations of love and desire in scientific, historical and religious contexts

Earth and environment go¬†hand-in-hand.¬†Think¬†big environmental problems like pollution, waste disposal and dam sites. The human impact on¬†environment¬†is a critical piece. But Earth Sciences helps put it all into perspective.¬†
To understand the earth and environment, you¬†have to¬†feel it and see it for yourself. You‚Äôll do that with¬†field courses¬†and¬†trips. Stay close to home and experience Georgian Bay and Manitoulin Island. Or go on an adventure with your classmates to an¬†international destination.¬†
At Western, there‚Äôs flexibility to add a related module to your degree, like biology, political science, or geography. Click into ‚Äúmore‚Äù to see modules and sample courses.

minor.introduction:
Bet you didn‚Äôt expect Science to come up in Arts  Humanities. But it‚Äôs a big part of linguistics: the scientific and humanistic study of language. It‚Äôs about using tools to analyze language function, but also exploring the historical and social variations in language.
Words are powerful and complex. From phonetics and phonology to syntax and semantics. If you don‚Äôt know these yet, you‚Äôll be an expert when you graduate.
Understanding every aspect of language is helpful for almost every profession. You might gravitate towards teaching, translation, and speech pathology. But technology is creating a new need for experts in linguistics. Think artificial intelligence and language/voice recognition programs. Linguistics will always be in-demand.

minor.introduction:
How does gender relate to race, ethnicity, socio-economic status, (dis)ability and age? Maybe you‚Äôve thought about it a little. But we‚Äôre going to blow it wide open. And we don‚Äôt shy away from controversial topics.

Is an inclusive feminism possible?
How does the law affect women?
How did homophobia aid the Cold War?
How are women represented in pop culture?
Should we be teaching people how to have sex or how not to have sex?
How do surveillance technologies aim to track, identify, and classify gender, race and sexuality?
Is there such a thing as queer time?

That‚Äôs a lot to unpack. But when you finish, you‚Äôll be a socially conscious citizen ready to make a difference in the world. With the skills you‚Äôll work on in writing and critical thinking, you‚Äôll be ready for careers in law, journalism, social work and more.

Fascinated with food? Interested in the nuances of nutrition? At Western, you‚Äôll be surrounded by curious, caring leaders in food innovation.¬†
Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll study:¬†

Human nutrition¬†
Global impact of the food industry¬†
Societal determinants of health¬†
Chemical composition of food¬†
Cultural influence on food habits¬†

Foods  Nutrition is offered at both Western University and Brescia University College.¬†Brescia is an affiliate of Western. The programs and modules in Foods  Nutrition are almost identical.¬†
So, which should you apply to? If you identify as female, you can apply to both Brescia and Western, since Brescia is Canada‚Äôs only female-only university. If you don‚Äôt identify as female, you‚Äôre welcome to apply to Western.

minor.introduction:
The laws of nature. At Western, you‚Äôre surrounded by classmates and professors as passionate about them as you are.¬†
Let these questions spark your curiosity:¬†

How do stars and planets form?¬†
How is medical physics used to develop diagnostic toolkits for cancer treatment?¬†
How do I track meteors falling to earth?¬†
How are next-generation technologies developed like nanofabrication, optoelectronic devices and biomaterials?¬†

Some physicists work in applied research. Some in engineering, medicine and teaching. Your future after Western could range from working as an industry scientist at a medical imaging company, to becoming a software specialist working with big data, or becoming a doctor.

minor.introduction:
Theatre makes you think and feel. It doesn‚Äôt fit into a traditional classroom, so we won‚Äôt put you there. Through seminars, workshops, productions and field trips, you‚Äôll be immersed in your learning experience.
You don‚Äôt have to audition or interview for this program. We‚Äôre not an acting school. But theatre studies is great preparation for a post-degree program in acting, directing and stage management.
What you learn will help you on and off the stage:

Creative expression
Self-confidence
Teamwork
Communication
Collaboration

Whether you want to get on stage or help behind the curtain, there are lots of shows to get in on. Through our Fall Theatre Production Course, Stratford Festival and Theatre Western, you'll take on everything from acting to props, costumes and marketing.

Explore multiple perspectives. Discover solutions. Collaborate and learn from your peers. Investigate society's most pressing issues in Integrated Science (WISc). Climate change? Alternative energy? Global pandemic? You‚Äôll tackle them all using an interdisciplinary approach.
WISc is a unique program that combines nine scientific disciplines. Engage in small, interactive classes. Develop scientific literacy. Refine your teamwork, leadership and communication skills. In the upper years, put your skills into practice by working with community partners. You‚Äôll graduate ready to make an impact.

And you get to choose courses that fit your future goals. Interested in journalism? Take courses in sports and news writing. Interested in science and health? minor.introduction:
See the sweep of line, the invitation of texture. The history of an object‚Äôs making. The story it is making.
Study the visual arts at Western in the company of ambitious, accomplished creators and academics. Our graduates go on to careers as award-winning artists, respected curators, museum administrators, and influential writers and scholars.
Our amazing facility surrounds you with the tools to move forward in your discipline:

Bright, open workshop and studio areas
Superbly equipped seminar rooms
Photography and printmaking areas
Purpose-built gallery

Invited speakers, strong ties to local galleries and museums, and many student-driven exhibits make this an exciting community in which to grow.

minor.introduction:
Why would anyone do that? Is that normal? Is it brain chemistry or peer pressure? Is it built-in or learned? How do we learn?
Study psychology with us and seek the data that explains human behaviour. With a graduate degree, you can go on to a career in psychology. Your undergraduate work on its own will give you great skills for any work with humans, such as education, medicine, law, marketing, etc. Plan your courses well and this subject can take you anywhere (because even if you become a solo lighthouse keeper, there you will be, still a human).

minor.introduction:
How do we know what we know? What is real? What is good? What is rational? These questions have started whole branches of philosophy. And, although they can take us to interesting and abstract places, they also circle back to critical and practical questions of modern life: 

If we want to protect our environment, what is it that is worth saving, and why?
Will robots take all our jobs? Will humans become cyborgs‚Äîor obsolete?
Are there universal ethical principles that can guide the conduct of multinational corporations?
How do biases manifest in scientific production? Does the gender of the knower make a difference?


Your courses in ethics, epistemology, metaphysics, and logic, as well as more specialized courses in philosophy of science, feminism, philosophy of mind and language, and applied ethics will develop and hone your skills as a reader, writer, analyst, and thinker.

minor.introduction:
Let‚Äôs talk politics. Societies have rules; within a polity (a society with common governance), we call the rules laws. Where do the rules come from? How and why do they change? What is the intention (policy) behind a rule? What does the data say about the consequences of a given policy? What do we know about political persuasion? Is a given change a positive trend or not?
We love these questions, and all their detailed variations. Study with us and you gain the skills essential to any profession, from analyzing data to communicating persuasively. Our graduates go on to careers in:

International business
Law
Politics  government
Media
University scholars  researchers

I think, therefore...neuroscience.¬†The focus of neuroscience is to understand how the most basic microscopic operations give rise to complex¬†behaviours¬†like language, music, or social interaction. Neuroscientists have a wide range of interests, from psychology to molecular biology, to understand the human brain¬†and its role in a healthy social, emotional, and physical life.¬†
Neuroscience¬†BSc:¬†Two Entry Paths¬†
You can apply to the¬†honours¬†specialization in Neuroscience (BSc) after your first year in either Medical Sciences or in the Faculty of Science. They have slightly different admission requirements, although both programs are part of the Faculty of Science.¬†¬†
Explore¬†Neuroscience BSc program details.

minor.introduction:
Step back and consider this odd social animal, the human. From religious rituals to neighbourhood games to rallies in the street‚Äîeverything we do is social. Our societies show common patterns and major differences. Why are we like this, or that? How do¬†(or don‚Äôt) we accommodate people who don‚Äôt fit in? How do we change, as a group?
You can study anything human within sociology‚Äîhealth, identity, inequality, gender, work. Criminology looks at crime, criminal behaviour, and deviance, all from a social science perspective.
